message_1: What is the ratio of carbon-14 to carbon-12 in a sample of organic material that is 5000 years old? Use the half-life of carbon-14 (5730 years) to calculate the answer.
message_2:
To calculate the ratio of carbon-14 to carbon-12 in a sample of organic material that is 5000 years old, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

N = N0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where:
N = the remaining amount of carbon-14 after time t
N0 = the initial amount of carbon-14
t = time elapsed (5000 years)
T = half-life of carbon-14 (5730 years)

Since we are looking for the ratio of carbon-14 to carbon-12, we can set N0 = 1 (assuming there was initially 1 unit of carbon-14). This means that the ratio will be equal to the remaining amount of carbon-14 (N) after 5000 years.

N = 1 * (1/2)^(5000/5730)

So, the ratio of carbon-14 to carbon-12 in a sample of organic material that is 5000 years old is approximately 0.765:1.
